title: My Aunt has a good point...

To be fair, the game gives you recommended items for each champion in real games. Unless you specifically remember that you got a Thornmail and specifically decide to ignore what you have been given as the recommended items, you'll probably build mostly correctly. 

There are still many problems with the tutorial, like that it's on Howling Abyss and that it uses Ashe, but I don't think the Thornmail is a huge problem.
Despite that it does that many new players do not understand that

Howling Abyss tutorial is bad.

Summoners Rift tutorial is not so bad.

People seem to forget the latter exists, for some reason. They really need to revamp the former, though.

You're teaching your aunt something more advanced than game basics. If, say, a new player was playing the game without a veteran's help, the armor would be good to show a fairly clear damage mitigation when you bought it. In fact, if I recall correctly, the Thornmail in that tutorial was *absurdly* more powerful than it is in real game. Save the specific stat attention for the more advanced (but still quite basic) tutorial.

If someone's learning the ropes, it's simply more helpful for you to do noticeably better defensively than offensively. If you end up chickening out when Trundle runs at you and running in circles screaming *toward the enemy tower* (I've seen it...), the game makes it more obvious that you have improved compared to your earlier self. However, if you can't focus him because you don't get that yet, you may hate this game before you get through the tutorial, which is the main thing they want to prevent...

Another thought that won't be popular. Some of the best monetary contributors end up being our more *casual* players. Sometimes, those types are just the ones who would give up after a horrific tutorial experience, particularly if someone's yelling behind them that they just fudged up the tutorial, and have huge mountains to climb. As I've said earlier, this I've also seen nearly happen, despite my efforts to teach.
